title: Hydrotherapy (Water Cure)
metaTitle: Hydrotherapy Treatment Delhi | Water Therapy Benefits
metaDescription: Experience the healing power of water with Hydrotherapy in Delhi. Treatments include Hip Bath, Spinal Spray, Steam Bath, and Wet Sheet Packs for immunity and circulation.
introduction:
Water is the world's first medicine.

Hydrotherapy is the application of water at varying temperatures (hot, cold, neutral) and states (liquid, steam, ice) to produce physiological changes in the body. It relies on the body's reaction to these thermal stimuli: Cold water constricts blood vessels (invigorating), while hot water dilates them (relaxing). Alternating them creates a pumping action that boosts circulation and immunity.

At Delhi Wellness Haven, our Hydrotherapy wing is equipped with specialized tubs, jets, and sprays to treat everything from back pain to insomnia.

sections.title: How Hydrotherapy Works
sections.content: Water has high specific heat and conductivity. When applied to the skin, it influences blood distribution. For example, a cold bath drives blood from the skin to the internal organs (improving organ function), while a hot pack draws blood to the surface (relieving deep congestion).

sections.title: Types of Treatments Available
sections.content:
Hip Bath

You sit in a special tub with water covering only the hips. Cold Hip Bath: Cures constipation, piles, and pelvic inflammation. Hot Hip Bath: Relieves menstrual pain and bladder infections.

Spinal Spray

A fine jet of water massages the entire spinal column. Excellent for back pain, anxiety, and insomnia. It calms the nervous system instantly.

Immersion Bath

Full body soak in varied temperatures. Epsom salt or herbal decoctions are often added for muscle relaxation and skin diseases.

Wet Sheet Pack

The body is wrapped in a cold wet sheet and then warm blankets. The body generates heat to dry the sheet, inducing a fever-like state that kills bacteria and eliminates toxins.

faq.question: Is cold water therapy safe for everyone?
faq.answer: It is generally safe, but we avoid extreme cold for patients with heart conditions or high blood pressure. Temperature is always prescribed by the doctor.
